title: Mangakakahi Stream treated like a 'rubbish dump'
text:
Mangakakahi Stream treated like a 'rubbish dump' Last updated 14:31, February 17 2017 BAY OF PLENTY REGIONAL COUNCIL 
Trash pulled from the Mangakakahi Stream in Rotorua this week. 
More than 200 kgs of waste, including used nappies, has been pulled from a Rotorua stream. 
The massive dump in the Mangakakahi Stream, which also included a lamp shade, double bed base and old TV, was discovered by a passerby who alerted the Bay of Plenty Regional Council to it via their Pollution Hotline. 
Council pollution prevention officer Mike Collins says a trailer was required to haul over 200 kilograms of waste from the stream to the Waste Management landfill. 
"It was not a pretty sight and a real shame to see one of our streams treated like a dump site," Collins said. 
Council staff spent three hours clearing and disposing of the rubbish and have urged people to take ownership for their own waste. 
"We are very fortunate to be surrounded by some of the country's most pristine streams and lakes and it is our responsibility to look after them. That means disposing our rubbish the correct way." 
Rotorua Lakes Council recently undertook a waste management makeover and has proved residents with wheelie bins for rubbish and recycling so Collins said there was no excuse for chucking household rubbish or any unwanted items in to waterways. 
"If you would like to swim and drink from it, cool down and even fish from your stream, think carefully about how you treat it. Everyone needs to do their part to keep our town clean and tidy." 
Collins said discharges to land, water and air in the Bay of Plenty Region could be reported to the Pollution Hotline via 0800 884 883. 
It was better is they did so at the time the pollution incident was occurring if possible and provide a clear description of the time, date, location and details of the pollution related incident. 
Local Council deals with discharges to open stormwater drains, stormwater systems and failures of reticulated sewerage systems. - Stuff
